author: samwilsn
content: `Price of ETH` divided by `Price of Oil`, back on a linear scale.

author: moatazelmasry
content: That is the price of oil for march 2022 delivery, so the data point for 2018 isn't a true representation of the price of oil at that time as it would be factoring in the cost of storing that oil all the way up to march 2022

author: moatazelmasry
content: I would recommend using CL1 ticker which is a forward roll of the prompt oil contract: https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/CL1:COM

author: moatazelmasry
content: So at any given point in time, CL1 will be the price of crude with earliest delivery in the futures market (spot market trades different contracts and delivery is earlier)

author: samwilsn
content: Hm, I need to get that data in a tractable format. Yahoo finance has a nice CSV export option...

author: moatazelmasry
content: is the above price data from yahoo finance? Yahoo calls it March 22 but the historic data would be for the corresponding prompt contract. So you can ignore what I said above if you are pulling the CL data from Yahoo.

author: samwilsn
content: Yes, that's where I'm grabbing it from

author: samwilsn
content: Specifically: https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/quote/CL%3DF/history?p=CL%3DF&.tsrc=fin-srch

author: moatazelmasry
content: you are looking at the right price then üëç

author: samwilsn
content: Looking at the charts, seems like ETH is falling compared to the "price of energy" (or our proxy for it). What does that mean exactly? üòõ

author: moatazelmasry
content: With recent geo-political incidents in the Middle East and Russia, hard to tell if the price of oil is going up because of supply / demand or speculation.

author: moatazelmasry
content: Maybe use a commodity index instead? It includes commodities like precious metals and agriculture: https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/%5EBCOM/
